item.title: Biden Is Hoping Small Changes Go a Long Way on Immigration
item.description: The United States has started to allow people to apply for asylum under a new process that the secretary of homeland security hopes can help fix the current “very broken system.”
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Miriam Jordan
item.media:credit: Jose Luis Gonzalez/Reuters
item.media:description: Asylum-seeking migrants walked out of the Rio Grande to turn themselves in to U.S. Border Patrol agents and request asylum in El Paso this month.

item.title: Lawmakers Propose Measure to Avert Government Shutdown
item.description: The vote on Tuesday will be a referendum on a bid to include Senator Joe Manchin’s plan to make it easier to build oil and gas infrastructure projects, including one in his home state of West Virginia.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane
item.media:credit: Shuran Huang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Funding for the government is set to run out when a new fiscal year begins on Saturday.

item.title: For a Deaf Family in Ukraine, War Is a Bewildering Terror
item.description: People with disabilities in the country are often isolated and poor, and for those like Antonina Andriyenko and her daughter, Tanya, the fear and confusion of trying to stay safe is a constant struggle.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Antonina Andriyenko, 74, on the balcony of her apartment in Kharkiv, Ukraine, in July. “We stayed because we didn’t know where to go,” she said.

item.title: The Stolen Babies of Spain
item.description: Under Francisco Franco’s rule, thousands of newborns were secretly taken from hospitals and sold to wealthy Catholic families. Now they are beginning to uncover their own histories.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Casey
item.media:credit: Lydia Metral for The New York Times. Source photograph from Ana Belén Pintado.
item.media:description: Ana Belén Pintado as a young girl.

item.title: House Jan. 6 Panel Faces Key Decisions as It Wraps Up Work
item.description: The committee investigating what led to the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol will hold its first hearing since July on Wednesday, entering the final stage of its inquiry.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater and Katie Benner
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Among the many unresolved issues before the House committee on Jan. 6 as it enters its final months is whether to subpoena former President Donald J. Trump to testify.

item.title: Inflation Has Hit Tenants Hard. What About Their Landlords?
item.description: Publicly traded corporate landlords are reporting some of their highest margins ever, while smaller operators say rent increases are eaten up by costs.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis
item.media:credit: Richard Beaven for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ryan Vienneau and his wife own 11 apartments in and around Saratoga Springs, N.Y.

item.title: Are Political Winds Blowing in Republicans’ Favor Again?
item.description: There are some signs of a drift toward issues where the party has an advantage, like the economy and immigration.
item.dc:creator: Nate Cohn
item.media:credit: Gabby Jones for The New York Times
item.media:description: Food prices, stock prices and other economic factors may be top priorities for voters in November.

item.title: A New Book Traces the Last, Painful Days of Anthony Bourdain
item.description: A new, unauthorized biography reveals intimate, often raw, details of the TV star’s life and death. And it’s drawing criticism from many of his friends and family.
item.dc:creator: Kim Severson
item.category: Down and Out in Paradise: The Life of Anthony Bourdain (Book)
item.media:credit: Alex Welsh for The New York Times
item.media:description: A new book about Anthony Bourdain reveals fresh details about his life and last days.

item.title: Jamie Raskin on The Second Amendment
item.description: It is essential to reject the myth that frustrated citizens have a right to raise arms against the government.
item.dc:creator: Jamie Raskin
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:credit: Nicole Hester/Ann Arbor News, via Associated Press

item.title: Russians Are Terrified and Have Nowhere to Turn
item.description: For citizens who want to escape conscription, there simply aren’t many options.
item.dc:creator: Ilia Krasilshchik
item.media:credit: Arkady Budnitsky/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Conscripted Russian men attending a farewell ceremony in Bataysk, Russia, on Monday.

item.title: Ron DeSantis Is Making an Asylum Crisis of His Own
item.description: Does America still embrace its international obligation to provide sanctuary to at least some unauthorized immigrants?
item.dc:creator: Dara Lind
item.media:credit: Illustration by Sam Whitney/The New York Times; images by Xuanyu Han and Gwengoat, via Getty Images

item.title: Trump’s Heartless QAnon Embrace
item.description: He’s reinforcing life-ruining delusions.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Goldberg
item.media:credit: Jeff Swensen/Getty Images

item.title: The Forgotten Lessons of the Recovered Memory Movement
item.description: A deep understanding of how cultural trends and psychology interact is more important than ever.
item.dc:creator: Ethan Watters
item.media:credit: Illustration by Mike McQuade. Photograph by Getty Images

item.title: Why Zombie Reaganomics Still Rules the G.O.P.
item.description: MAGA is in charge, but policy caters to the wealthy.
item.dc:creator: Paul Krugman
item.media:credit: Charles Krupa/Associated Press

item.title: Why Candidates Like John Fetterman Owe Voters Full Medical Transparency
item.description: Health doesn’t have to be so political.
item.dc:creator: Lawrence K. Altman
item.media:credit: Kriston Jae Bethel/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Lt. Gov. John Fetterman of Pennsylvania greets supporters following a Senate campaign rally.

item.title: China’s Huge Appetite for Fish
item.description: Why are Chinese boats catching so many fish off the Galápagos Islands?
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Isaac Haslam/Sea Shepherd, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A Chinese ship fishing off the west coast of South America in July 2021.

item.title: The Great Pandemic Theft
item.description: As the coronavirus swept the United States, the government spent vast sums to help shield the economy. But billions of dollars of that aid disappeared.
item.dc:creator: Michael Barbaro, Rob Szypko, Jessica Cheung, Luke Vander Ploeg, Mooj Zadie, MJ Davis Lin, John Ketchum, Marion Lozano, Elisheba Ittoop and Chris Wood
item.media:credit: Shari L. Gross/Star Tribune, via Associated Press

item.title: Modern Love Podcast: How to Feel Yourself
item.description: At 83, and legally blind, a woman needs help with one of her favorite pastimes: visiting the sex shop.
item.media:credit: Brian Rea

item.title: Keir Starmer Accuses Liz Truss of Losing Control of Britain’s Economy
item.description: Under the governing Conservatives, the markets are down and the pound is under pressure. On Thursday, Keir Starmer, the Labour leader, staked his claim as the guardian of sound fiscal policy.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Henry Nicholls/Reuters
item.media:description: Keir Starmer, the leader of Britain’s opposition Labour Party, used his party conference speech on Tuesday in Liverpool to talk about how his party would try to solve the economic crisis.

item.title: Biden’s Support for Iran Protesters Comes After Bitter Lessons of 2009
item.description: President Biden has quickly backed demonstrators in Iran. When the country faced similar unrest 13 years ago, U.S. officials feared such a strong approach would be counterproductive.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Wana News Agency/Via Reuters
item.media:description: Protests in Tehran last week. The Biden administration has pushed to get satellite systems into the hands of anti-government officials in Iran.

item.title: NASA Smashes Into an Asteroid, Completing a Mission to Save a Future Day
item.description: The DART spacecraft completed its 10-month journey to demonstrate a technique that could defend the planet from deadly space rocks in the future.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.category: Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory
item.media:credit: NASA/Johns Hopkins APL
item.media:description: The asteroid Dimorphos 11 seconds before NASA’s DART spacecraft collided with it on Monday.

item.title: Jails Boss Pushed for Dying Man’s Release to Limit Rikers Death Count
item.description: Louis A. Molina, New York City’s jail commissioner, told his senior staff to ensure that a dying man was “off the department’s count.”
item.dc:creator: Jan Ransom
item.media:credit: Andrew Seng for The New York Times
item.media:description: Louis A. Molina, commissioner of the New York City Department of Corrections, at a news conference at Rikers Island after three incarcerated inmates died in June.

item.title: The Health Benefits of Chia Seeds
item.description: Chia seeds are back (again) — and nutritionists and doctors say there are good reasons for it.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum
item.media:credit: Adam Friedlander for The New York Times

item.title: Is It Better to Cook With Coconut Oil or Olive Oil?
item.description: Proponents of coconut oil point out that it is rich in phytochemicals with healthful properties. But so is olive oil.
item.dc:creator: Sophie Egan
item.media:credit: Andrew Scrivani for The New York Times

item.title: How Much Sugar Is in a Glass of Wine?
item.description: Winemakers may add sugar to wine to “improve” the taste, and sugar content can vary widely.
item.dc:creator: Sophie Egan
item.media:credit: Tony Cenicola/The New York Times

item.title: Is Alkaline Water Really Better for You?
item.description: What’s behind the claims that alkaline water will “energize” and “detoxify” the body and lead to “superior hydration”?
item.dc:creator: Alice Callahan
item.media:credit: iStock

item.title: Testosterone Levels: Can Specific Foods or Diets Boost Them?
item.description: What you eat or drink may affect levels of the male sex hormone, but whether a diet can increase libido or energy depends on many things.
item.dc:creator: Randi Hutter Epstein, M.D.
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: In Malibu, an Inflatable Bungalow for Robert Downey Jr.
item.description: The actor’s thin-shell home is at once an aerodynamic oddity and, perhaps, a harbinger of environmentally conscious architecture.
item.dc:creator: Nick Haramis and Joyce Kim

item.title: How to Solve Beginner Crosswords
item.description: Get started solving the Mini, Monday and Tuesday puzzles.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
item.media:credit: Thomas Merceron
